Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Learning across the Expert-Novice Continuum: Cognition in the Geosciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Two related research projects will investigate cognition across undergraduate geology majors, geology graduate students, and professional geologists. The field-based studies involve authentic tasks commonly used by students and professional geoscientists. Navigation (GPS) as well as cognitive (maps, audio logs, and debriefing interviews) data will allow the investigators to study complex natural problem solving. The laboratory studies involve a series of cognitive tasks that allow the investigation of working memory function, perceptual abilities, and the structuring of domain-specific content knowledge. The investigators expect to produce: (1) Valid and reliable methods
for investigating field-based geologic cognition and navigation, which could allow for field-based cognitive data to be readily collected from large numbers of students enrolled in field courses; (2) New laboratory-based cognitive experiments that push the boundaries of existing knowledge about the cognitive processes underlying the learning and teaching of complex geoscience content, which will bridge the geoscience education and cognitive science literatures on STEM learning; and (3) A theoretical model for geocognition derived from empirical data that describes how cognitive processes manifest and change as students progress toward expertise, which will provide a foundation for research-based instructional design and teaching in the
geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on differences between professional and student geologists, considering the extent to which specific variables impact learning and performance. We were particularly interested in understanding whether two innate characteristics, working memory capacity and spatial visualization skill, related to expertise. Working memory capacity relates to how much information someone can hold in their mind at one time, while spatial visualization considers how well someone can manipulate objects in space within their mind.

We collected two data sets, one in the laboratory and one in the field. The laboratory data set allowed us to consider differences in working memory capacity and spatial visualization between professionals and students. We found that working memory capacity had little relationship to expertise, while spatial visualization seemed minimally related. These data informed our field study. In this study, 67 geologists, undergraduates, graduate students, and professionals, were each taken to a field site in Montana for two days. During these two days, the geologists completed a set of tests measuring psychological variables like working memory capacity and spatial visualization skill and completed a field mapping task that lasted between 3 and 9 hours. Analysis of collected data indicates that spatial visualization skill is helpful to student geologists, but had no impact once geologists reached mapping expertise. We also found, through use of GPS units tracking geologists’ movement through the field, that expert geologists may plan their movements early in the mapping process. Student geologists seem to modify their large scale movements much more in response to data immediately encountered in the field.

These studies provide useful insight into new approaches that can be used to train geologists to work more effectively in the field. In addition, this work challenges assumptions about the overall importance of spatial visualization skill for expert behavior, perhaps opening up geoscience as a career opportunity for students with lower spatial skill.
